verdict:
HIGH RISK: Many defensive patterns implemented incorrectly. This codebase has adopted resilience theater - patterns that look good but add failure modes rather than preventing them. The complexity likely makes the system LESS reliable.

WARNING: 6 different resilience libraries detected. This suggests copy-paste from multiple sources without a coherent strategy.

recommendations.message: 91 high-severity issues found that likely cause production problems
actions: git-p4.py:206 - Retry without backoff - will cause thundering herd on failure
git-p4.py:206 - Retry without maximum attempts - may retry forever
git-p4.py:888 - Retry without backoff - will cause thundering herd on failure
git-p4.py:888 - Retry without maximum attempts - may retry forever
git-p4.py:1316 - Retry without backoff - will cause thundering herd on failure
Add exponential backoff: delay = base_delay * (2 ** attempt)
Add jitter: delay * (1 + random.uniform(-0.1, 0.1))
Consider using tenacity or backoff libraries
Add timeout to all HTTP clients: requests.get(url, timeout=(5, 30))
Use connect_timeout and read_timeout separately
Default suggestion: 5s connect, 30s read

recommendations.message: 39 circuit breakers without metrics or logging
actions: Add state change callbacks: on_state_change=lambda: metrics.emit(...)
Log circuit breaker state transitions
Expose circuit breaker state as a metric

recommendations.message: 6 locations where exceptions are silently ignored
actions: At minimum, log the exception before ignoring
Consider whether the exception should propagate
Use specific exception types instead of bare except

recommendations.message: 6 resilience libraries in use - consider consolidating
actions: Pick one retry library and use it consistently
Document the resilience strategy in a central place
Current libraries: glib, gsl, libbsd, libcurl, openssl, pthreads

recommendations.message: Resilience patterns are adding complexity without benefit
actions: Consider removing retry/circuit breaker patterns until properly implemented
Simple code that fails obviously is better than complex code that fails silently
Start with timeouts and logging, add other patterns only when needed
